document_metadata.description: Heme BEL model is a disease model based on Biological Expression Language (BEL) containing the core mechanisms of heme as modulator in Hemolytic diseases such as sickle-cell anemia, beta-thalassemia, malaria and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.
document_metadata.name: heme_29544683.bel

citation.name: Effects of Histidine-rich glycoprotein on erythrocyte aggregation and hemolysis: Implications for a role under septic conditions.

links.evidence: Eryptosis is the apoptotic-like suicidal process of erythrocytes, and is characterized by cell shrinkage and phosphatidylserine (PS) expression on the outer membrane.

citation.name: Effects of Histidine-rich glycoprotein on erythrocyte aggregation and hemolysis: Implications for a role under septic conditions.

links.evidence: Although neutrophils, platelets and vascular endothelial cells are the main effector cells involved in immunothrombosis, abnormal aggregation of erythrocytes under septic conditions may also contribute to immunothrombosis in sepsis.

citation.name: Effects of Histidine-rich glycoprotein on erythrocyte aggregation and hemolysis: Implications for a role under septic conditions.

links.evidence: The cascade of immunothrombosis includes platelet activation and secretion, which may result in a local increase in Zn2þ concentration because of the presence of Zn2þ in platelet dense granules.

links.evidence: Stimulation with 20 mM Zn2þ resulted in aggregation of washed human erythrocytes 1 h after incubation.

citation.name: Effects of Histidine-rich glycoprotein on erythrocyte aggregation and hemolysis: Implications for a role under septic conditions.

links.evidence: Thus focusing on Zn2þ-stimulated erythrocytes might be an important new approach that could ultimately reveal the mechanism of immunothrombus formation in sepsis.

citation.name: Effects of Histidine-rich glycoprotein on erythrocyte aggregation and hemolysis: Implications for a role under septic conditions.

links.evidence: HRG strongly inhibited the aggregation at a concentration of 1 mg/mL, whereas the same concentration of HSA showed no effect (Fig. 1B).

citation.name: Effects of Histidine-rich glycoprotein on erythrocyte aggregation and hemolysis: Implications for a role under septic conditions.

links.evidence: HRG and HSA both strongly inhibited aggregation when the concentration was increased to 100 mg/mL (Supplementary Fig. 1).

citation.name: Effects of Histidine-rich glycoprotein on erythrocyte aggregation and hemolysis: Implications for a role under septic conditions.

links.evidence: HRG and HSA both inhibited PS expression when their concentrations were increased to 10 and 100 mg/mL (Fig. 2B).

citation.name: Effects of Histidine-rich glycoprotein on erythrocyte aggregation and hemolysis: Implications for a role under septic conditions.

links.evidence: Surprisingly, HRG at high concentration (100 mg/mL) significantly decreased PS expression on erythrocytes.

citation.name: Effects of Histidine-rich glycoprotein on erythrocyte aggregation and hemolysis: Implications for a role under septic conditions.

links.evidence: HRG treatment significantly inhibited the attachment of erythrocytes to the vascular endothelial cell monolayer in a concentration dependent manner (Fig. 4A and B), while HSA did not affect the adhesion.

citation.name: Effects of Histidine-rich glycoprotein on erythrocyte aggregation and hemolysis: Implications for a role under septic conditions.

links.evidence: The decrease was due to the reduction in HRG gene expression, deposition of HRG on immunothrombi and degradation of HRG by thrombin.
